user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskDelete:
```c
int32 OS_TaskDelete(osal_id_t task_id)
{
    int32                      return_code;
    OS_object_token_t          token;
    OS_task_internal_record_t *task;
    osal_task_entry            delete_hook;

    delete_hook = NULL;
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        task = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_task_table, token);

        /* Save the delete hook, as we do not want to call it while locked */
        delete_hook = task->delete_hook_pointer;

        return_code = OS_TaskDelete_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    /*
    ** Call the thread Delete hook if there is one.
    */
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS && delete_hook != NULL)
    {
        delete_hook();
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskDelete:
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_TaskDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_task_internal_record_t *impl;
    void *                          retval;
    int                             ret;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_task_table, *token);

    /*
    ** Try to delete the task
    ** If this fails, not much recourse - the only potential cause of failure
    ** to cancel here is that the thread ID is invalid because it already exited itself,
    ** and if that is true there is nothing wrong - everything is OK to continue normally.
    */
    ret = pthread_cancel(impl->id);
    if (ret != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("pthread_cancel: Failed on Task ID = %lu, err = %s\n",
                 OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(ret));

        /* fall through (will still return OS_SUCCESS) */
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * Note that "pthread_cancel" is a request - and successful return above
         * only means that the cancellation request is pending.
         *
         * pthread_join() will wait until the thread has actually exited.
         *
         * This is important for CFE, as task deletion often occurs in
         * conjunction with an application reload - which means the next
         * call is likely to be OS_ModuleUnload().  So is critical that all
         * tasks potentially executing code within that module have actually
         * been stopped - not just pending cancellation.
         */
        ret = pthread_join(impl->id, &retval);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("pthread_join: Failed on Task ID = %lu, err = %s\n",
                     OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(ret));
        }
    }
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int32 operation_status, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    osal_id_t final_id;

    /* Clear the OSAL ID if successful - this returns the record to the pool */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        final_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    }
    else
    {
        /* this restores the original ID */
        final_id = token->obj_id;
    }

    /* Either way we must unlock the object type */
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, &final_id);

    /* Give event callback to the application */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_NotifyEvent(OS_EVENT_RESOURCE_DELETED, token->obj_id, NULL);
    }

    return operation_status;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_task_internal_record_t OS_task_table[LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS]
...
typedef struct
{
    char            task_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    size_t          stack_size;
    osal_priority_t priority;
    osal_task_entry entry_function_pointer;
    osal_task_entry delete_hook_pointer;
    void *          entry_arg;
    osal_stackptr_t stack_pointer;
} OS_task_internal_record_t
...
typedef osal_task((*osal_task_entry)(void))
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I examined all code in the target function and the related definitions for constructs that would constitute compiler/language extensions (examples: GNU __attribute__ or __extension__ tokens, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, inline assembly (__asm__), nonstandard pragmas, compiler builtins with compiler-specific names, or other documented compiler-only keywords). None of these appear.

Specific observations that justify not reporting fragments:
- The use of pthread_cancel, pthread_join, strerror and pthread types are POSIX library calls, not compiler language extensions.
- The macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) expands to standard C expressions and uses the address-of operator on an expression; this is standard C and not a language extension.
- The typedef for a function-pointer type and use of function-pointer variables (delete_hook) are standard C.
- The static inline helper (OS_ObjectIndexFromToken) uses the inline keyword, which is part of standard C (since C99), not a compiler extension.
- There are no occurrences of identifiers or tokens that are commonly compiler-specific (no __attribute__, __asm__, __builtin_*, typeof, labels-as-values, statement-expressions, or other known extensions).

Based on the provided code, there are no fragments that explicitly use compiler-documented language extensions, so nothing needs to be flagged for investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
